Within the framework of trade in the Red Sea, agents were used on different points of the route, but their social status and consequently the legal and/or social form of principal-agent relationship depended on the social and cultural background of the people engaged in this trade: Romans used freedmen and slaves as agents, while Alexandrians and other people of Roman Egypt preferred to use free agents.
